author: gumb00
content: I guess set code transaction can also be creation transaction with empty `destination`. What happens if both the `authorization_list` and initcode execution result set code of the same address, I guess initcode wins?

author: lightclient
content: empty list is valid and setting code is not rolled back if the tx reverts. should probably just ban creation txs via 7702

author: _shemnon
content: If setting code is permanent perhaps just ban all calls not just creation transactions.  The next TX will get it. It does close a one-time mev-proof window however.

author: lightclient
content: sorry not sure i understand this?

author: _shemnon
content: Banning creation transactions to prevent some corner case because of them reverting or address collision won't cover all the cases.  The same collisionons can happen by calling create in a normal tx call, or have the normal call revert for any number of reasons.  I don't understand why create transactions create a different issue.

author: lightclient
content: I don't think create transactions cause an issue per se, I just think there is no need for create so we should make `destination` required like 4844 and keep it simple

author: _shemnon
content: It's better to ban and relax then to allow and ban, but I think there are useful cases where a contract creation could depend on a proxy being set (or a creation of a contract based on a blob being present, such as genesis of an L2). But the practicality of banning for ease of testing is compelling.
